nodes.text: Geography (place where a child grows up) is a major determinant of intergenerational economic mobility in the United States

Method: Use deidentified federal tax records on >40 million children and their parents (1996–2012) to measure parent family income (mean 1996–2000) and child family income (mean 2011–2012) and assign children to commuting zones (CZs) based on ZIP where claimed as dependents

Method: Summarize mobility with rank-rank regressions within national distribution (child rank R on parent rank P): approximate linearity yields two CZ-level parameters, slope (relative mobility) and intercept -> absolute mobility r25 = intercept + 25*slope

Result (national): The rank-rank relationship is almost perfectly linear nationally; estimated rank-rank slope is 0.341 so a 10 percentile increase in parent rank associates with a 3.41 percentile increase in child rank on average

Claim: The canonical log-log intergenerational income elasticity (IGE) is unstable in these administrative data because of nonlinearity and treatment of zero incomes; IGE estimates vary widely (e.g., 0.26–0.70) across specifications

Result (spatial variation): Intergenerational mobility varies substantially across commuting zones; examples: probability of moving from bottom quintile to top quintile is 4.4% in Charlotte, 12.9% in San Jose; absolute upward mobility r25 among 50 largest CZs ranges from 35.8 (Charlotte) to 46.2 (Salt Lake City)

Result: Relative and absolute mobility are strongly correlated across CZs (unweighted corr approx -0.68 between rank-rank slope and r25); areas with higher relative mobility tend to yield better absolute outcomes for children from low-income families

Result (timing): Spatial gradients in college attendance and teenage birth by parent income mirror income mobility patterns, implying differences emerge while children are growing up rather than only after labor market entry

Claim: Areas with high upward mobility share five correlated features: (i) less residential segregation, (ii) less income inequality (especially within bottom 99%), (iii) better K-12 school outcomes, (iv) greater social capital, and (v) greater family stability (fewer single parents)

Evidence: Cross-CZ correlations (univariate) are strong: segregation index ~ -0.36 with r25; Gini ~ -0.58 with r25; social capital index ~ +0.64 with r25; fraction single-parent households ~ -0.76 with r25; school output measures (income-adjusted test scores, dropout) correlate ~0.6 with r25

Claim on interpretation and causality: The analysis is descriptive and cross-sectional, so correlations should not be taken as causal; however, follow-up work (Chetty and Hendren 2014) shows that a substantial portion of spatial variation is driven by causal effects of place using quasi-experimental designs

Limitation: Measurement choices matter for some measures (e.g., IGE sensitive to zeros and log-specification) and all covariates are endogenously determined, limiting causal inference from these correlations

Conclusion: Location matters greatly for children's economic prospects; CZ-level mobility estimates are publicly available and can guide future causal research and place-based policies to improve upward mobility
